abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the project were as
            follows: the outcome was satisfactory, the sustainability
            was likely, the institutional development impact was
            substantial, and the Bank and borrower performance were both
            satisfactory. The lessons learned indicate that in Indonesia
            where the legal system has proven ineffective in enforcing
            the repayment of debt, the willingness of Government to step
            in and see to it that corporate restructuring takes place
            was critical. The success of the Jakarta Initiative Task
            Force (JITF) process has demonstrated the usefulness of
            alternative dispute resolution (ADR) in Indonesia. The
            voluntary nature of the JITF process did not work well until
            an adequate incentive framework had been created. It is
            important for the Government to take the lead in formulating
            policies and designing mechanisms where fundamental changes
            such as those supported by this Project are planned.
            Political commitment needs to be demonstrated and cannot be
            assumed. In a crisis situation, sufficient time and
            attention need to be given to a rigorous project preparation
            process: researching, assessing options, discussing and
            getting full Government buy-in and designing effective
            project management structures, before going ahead with
            implementation. A lesson from this Project is that
            inadequate attention and time saved in Project preparation
            can be a false economy. Field based supervision was
            important in this project because of the rapidly evolving
            crisis situation. When new institutions are being created
            and are untested, such as the Commercial Court and the JITF,
            care should be taken to guard against making optimistic
            assumptions and projections concerning their likely
            effectiveness and performance. Preparation of a financial
            management/procurement manual at the outset of a project and
            training of PIU staff in its use can help ensure smooth
            operations and minimize problems with procurement, payments
            and disbursements.
